transcripts.text: So can you tell us in the video, please, why you asked us for our IDs, please?
Ma'am, the reason I asked you for your ID is because I came in here and I saw that you guys are speaking Spanish, which is very unheard of up here.

He asked us when we were born first.  So that was a very weird question for somebody to ask you, you know?  So after that, he said he needed to see our IDs.  I'm not doing anything wrong.  You know why I need to feel like I need to give him my ID?
The Jews because our purple, right?  No.  Racial?
That has nothing to do with that.
It's the fact that it has to do with you guys speaking Spanish in the store.
In a state where it's predominantly English speaking.

I was in the store, and there was this Mexican guy.  He was the cashier.  I was speaking Spanish to my friend, and then he was like, don't, don't, don't, don't speak Spanish because two ladies, and I said, it's okay, one of the ladies is me, and it's okay, you speak Spanish.
My daughter was also Like, Mommy, are you sure we can speak Spanish?  I say something in Spanish and she answers to me in English because she's scared.  This changed our lives.  I will live forever.
You don't have the right to stop me.  Just because I speak Spanish.  And you know that.
To me, it's important to help the community, to help them know that they can speak whatever they want.
My friend told me, oh, they picked the wrong person.  I say, no, they picked the right person.  The person is going to stand up for the next one.
